poem:
The Politics of Limbs

On a bright morning, 
birds sing above the din 
of muddled orders, 
each instruction a pebble 
skipped across a turbulent lake.  
Shoot their legs, not their hearts,
splinter their bones rather than their dreams—  
a prescription to hobble protest, 
yet the world's still watching 
as silence loads its gun.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Shoot them in the leg’: Kenyan president’s anti-protest rhetoric hardens as death toll rises Kenya’s president, William Ruto, has ordered police to shoot protesters targeting businesses in the legs, in a sharp intensification of his rhetoric days after 31 people were killed in nationwide anti-government demonstrations. “They shouldn’t kill them but they should shoot their legs so they break and they can go to hospital on their way to court,” Ruto said in the capital,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
